items: Identify the intended audience: Consider their expertise level (collaborators, journal readers, students, general public) and adjust complexity accordingly.
Establish a clear purpose: What message should the figure convey? Focus on user-centric outcomes and ensure the figure supports this message.
Determine the core takeaway message: What is the single most important point you want the audience to understand?

steps: Determine core takeaway message: What is the single most important point you want the audience to understand?
Identify supporting evidence requirements: What data or information is needed to support your message?
Evaluate complexity needs: How much detail is necessary to convey your message effectively?

notes: Adjust element sizes and thickness accordingly.

Color Psychology: Use color intentionally. Blue conveys trust and calm, while red suggests urgency and alarm.
Scale Considerations: Use appropriate scaling for accurate data representation.
Avoid misleading scales that create false equivalencies.
Ensure data ranges reflect meaningful distinctions.
Data Normalization: Use population-adjusted metrics for better comparisons.
Consider underlying variables that affect interpretation.

Visual Hierarchy: Structure information in a logical order.
Break complex information into digestible sections.

Image Data Types.Raster Data: Use for complex images (photos, microscopy). Resolution dependent.
Image Data Types.Vector Data: Use for charts, diagrams, text. Resolution independent.

Color Models.CMYK: Used in printing. Consider if required by the journal.

Bit Depth: Use 8-bit for publication. Downsample higher bit depths carefully.

main_points: Chart type selection: Choose based on data characteristics.
Visual hierarchy optimization: Guide the reader's eye.
Appropriate scaling and labeling: Ensure clarity and accuracy.

types: Cartoons: Simplified illustrations focusing on core concept elements.
Flowcharts: Process visualization and decision pathway mapping.
Symbolic Representation: Parameter distillation and abstract element visualization.

Image-Based Figures: Background control: Ensure a clean background.
Diagram/model creation: Use diagrams to explain complex images.
Component labeling: Clearly label all parts of the image.
Schematic accompaniment: Provide a schematic to aid understanding.

Reference Implementation: Scale bar inclusion: Always include scale bars when appropriate.
Relatable size comparisons: Use common objects for size reference.
Common knowledge anchoring: Relate data to familiar concepts.
Signal-to-Noise Optimization: Data selectivity: Focus on the most important data.
Minimal non-critical elements: Remove unnecessary visual elements.
Strategic emphasis using color/bold: Highlight key information.
Clear, direct labeling: Use concise and informative labels.
Message-focused titles: Ensure titles clearly convey the figure's message.

guidelines: Push format decisions to the end of the workflow.
Maintain highest quality until final export.
Create backup copies at key stages.
Don't rely on software defaults. Customize fonts, colors, axes, etc.
Avoid misleading elements. Use appropriate scales and axes.
Eliminate chartjunk. Remove unnecessary visual elements.
Prioritize message over aesthetics. Focus on clarity and readability.

items: Design is appropriate for target audience
Colors are used effectively and accessibly
Format is suitable for intended medium
